This report was authored by a World Bank Group task team led by Lorenzo Carrera, Veruschka Schmidt, and Cyril Desponts.

The report benefited from invaluable inputs from a wider task team that included Abdoulaye Boly, Ahmed Al Qabany, Anna Carlotta Allen Massingue, Antonio Manuel Baptista, Anupurba Roy, Asha Johnson, Camila Mejia Giraldo, Christina Jutta Paul, Claudia Soto, Cyrille Valence Ngouana Kengne, Daniel Valderrama Gonzalez, Daniela Marotta, Damien Matthias Valentin Boucher, Emily Elaine Gardner, Eduardo Carbonel, Elisson M. Wright, Fabio Aparecido da Silva, Fred Kizito, GianLeo Frisari, Jorge Barreto, Jia Jun Lee, Karamba Badio, Laura Ximena Bermeo Rojas, Laurent Damblat, Louise Twining-Ward, Luisa Teixeira De Melo De C Felino, Luca Bernasconi, Marc-Anton Wilhelm Pruefer, Mathias Shabanaj Jankila, Michel Matera, Miles Bernard Johnson, Miguel Angel Jorge, Miguel Heleno, Nyandeng V. Gajang, Oscar Anil Ishizawa Escudero, Philippe Neves, Rafael Pardo, Raluca Georgiana Golumbeanu, Rodrigo Andrade, Rodrigo Pereira Porto, Ronak Makhani, Rosa Brito Delgado, Shreya Rangarajan, Sujatha Venkat Ganeshan, Tom Remy, Unnada Chewpreecha, and Zineb Benkirane.

The team would like to extend sincere thanks to the Industrial Economics (IEc) team of Brent Boehlert, Diego Castillo, Kim Smet, and Kenneth Strzepek, who led the impact channel and adaptation modeling.

The team benefited immensely from the guidance of, and is grateful to, the peer reviewers: Craig Meisner, Kodzovi Senu Abalo, Pablo Andres Salas Bravo, Philippe Ambrosi and Urvashi Narain. Additional guidance was also received from Sebastian Molineus, Victor Bundi Mosoti, and Kevin Carey.

Additionally, the task team would like to express heartfelt gratitude to the participants in the Country Climate and Development Report (CCDR) consultations for their availability, their collaborative spirit, and the quality of their contributions. They comprise representatives of ministries, government agencies, academia, civil society, the private sector, and the development community. A special thanks goes to Gilson Pina and Andrea Lucy Martins from the Ministry of Finance, and to Alexandre Nevsky Rodrigues from the Ministry of Agriculture and Environment.

Thanks are also extended to World Bank management and their teams for their guidance, in particular, Keiko Meiwa, Chakib Jenane, Olivier Buyoya, Moritz Nikolaus, Abebe Adugna, Eneida Fernandes, Indira Campos, Ellysar Baroudy, Kanta Kumari, Edouard Al-Dahdah, Frederic Verdol, Asha Johnson, Rebekka E. Grun, and Angela Armstrong.
Editorial support and graphical design were provided by Global Corporate Solutions Translation and Interpretation Services (GCSTI).

description: This image from the Cabo Verde Country and Climate Development Report shows a dramatic coastal landscape. A towering, dark, rocky cliff face dominates the left side of the frame, plunging down towards a turbulent, deep blue ocean. Waves crash against the shore, creating white foam. In the foreground, a stone wall runs along what appears to be a coastal path or road. The sky above is a mix of blue with scattered white clouds. The overall impression is one of rugged natural beauty, characteristic of the volcanic islands of Cabo Verde.

content: Cabo Verde Â© David Boutin Photography / iStock
Climate change will compound Cabo Verde's economic and climate vulnerabilities

**As a small island developing state (SIDS), Cabo Verde is highly vulnerable to extreme climate events.** Some 500 km off the west coast of Africa, it is an archipelago of ten islands with a population of 556,000, half of them on Santiago Island. Because of its location, Cabo Verde is highly vulnerable to natural hazards, including extreme heat, floods, droughts, tropical storms, landslides, volcanic eruptions, coastal erosion and sea level rise. This vulnerability is compounded by its sparse population and archipelagic geography, which make inter-island connectivity and hence service provision challenging, yet increase the population's dependence on maritime transport. Structural factors such as rapid ruralâurban migration and land degradation further aggravate the country's vulnerability to natural hazards.

On average, adverse natural events have historically been associated with a decrease in GDP per capita of almost 1 percentage point in the year of impact. Approximately a third of Cabo Verdeans are at risk of being affected by an extreme climate event, especially droughts and floods.

**Cabo Verde's climate exposure, partly also because of its geography, is compounded by economic vulnerabilities.** The country has experienced robust economic growth since the early 1990s and achieved a substantial reduction in poverty, but growth has been volatile and has slowed in recent years. Reflecting the comparative advantage of its attractive natural geography, growth has primarily been driven by the tourism sector, which accounts for a quarter of GDP, over half of exports, and most foreign direct investment. For similar reasons, the archipelago is heavily reliant on imports, notably those of fuel and food. High levels of remittance and concessional international financing serve to bridge its external financing needs but they generate additional external vulnerabilities. Adding to this, although recurrent fiscal deficits have recently resorbed, public spending is rigid1 and public debt remains above 100 percent of GDP. The COVID-19 pandemic put Cabo Verde's external vulnerabilities on display, causing a steep decline in tourism revenue and a surge in the food and fuel import bill before the economy returned to pre-pandemic conditions in 2023.
